title: HDA Colors
text:
HDAdvisors uses a four-color palette.

library(scales)
library(chroma)

pal <- c(
  "#445ca9", # Blue
  "#8baeaa", # Green
  "#e9ab3f", # Yellow
  "#e76f52"  # Coral
  )

scales::show_col(pal, borders = "#ffffff")










Note



We’ve asked our marketing consultant to provide two additional colors for this palette. This would allow for categorical color schemes for data with more than four variables.

title: HFV Colors
text:
HousingForward Virginia uses a six-color palette.

library(scales)
library(chroma)

hfv_pal <- c(
  "#011e41", # Shadow
  "#40c0c0", # Sky
  "#8b85ca", # Lilac
  "#259591", # Grass
  "#b1005f", # Berry
  "#e0592a"  # Desert
  )

scales::show_col(hfv_pal, borders = "#ffffff", cex_label = 0.8)

title: Inspiration
text:
A custom solution for HDA’s graphic production needs should preferably include the following:

Ability to manage and use at least two brand palettes for data visualization

HDA palette
HFV palette

Pre-made color scales

Categorical (up to 6 variables)
Sequential (several color options)
Diverging (at least 2 options)

Standard chart layout(s) using pre-defined theme() options in ggplot2

Label formatting (title, subtitle, axes, caption)
Layout formatting (axis lines, axis labels, gridlines, ticks, legends, etc.)

Ability to load and use custom fonts via Google Fonts

HDA fonts

title: Setup
text: The pages in this section show you how to create, design, and publish graphics that use brands managed by HDA. For now, this guide is only for production in RStudio using the suite of tidyverse packages (including ggplot2) and custom theming functions created to expedite consistent brand features.
